clinical_study.brief_title: Pre-procedure Modle Predicts Bowel Preparation Quality Prior Colonoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Pre-procedure Modle Predicts Bowel Preparation Quality Prior Colonoscopy

brief_summary.textblock: Bowel preparation is closely llined to the quality of colonoscopy, inadequate bowel preparation (IBP) could lead to higher miss rate of adenomas, patients' discomfort and higher health expense. For the patients with possible IBP before the examination, it may be better to cancel the colonoscopy and repeat bowel preparation through modified or enhanced strategies. Thus, it is important to set up a model to predict the quality of bowel preparation individually.

primary_outcome.description: A 10-point scale (0 is worst, 9 is best)

arm_group.description: This cohort was used to establish the bowel preparation score (BPS).
This cohort was used to verify the bowel preparation score (BPS).

intervention.description: Patients were asked to complete a questionnaire before colonoscopy. Bowel preparation was subsequently assessed by single endoscopist in each center using Boston bowel preparation quality score (BBPS). Both univariate and multivariate logistic regression models were used to identify high-risk factors associated with IBP and a predicting model with the bowel preparation score (BPS) was developed in the training cohort.

Patients were asked to complete a questionnaire before colonoscopy. The predicting modle established by the training cohort will be used to assessing the preparation of validation cohort. The result will compared with endoscopists assessment of preparation.

study_pop.textblock: This is a prospective study involving two tertiary-centers in China.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged 18-90 years old who undergoing colonoscopy
Exclusion Criteria:
- failed colonoscopy because of technical chanllenge or poor tolerance of patients
- history of colorectal surgery
- prior finding of severe colonic stricture or obstructing tumor
- dysphagia
- compromised swallowing reflex or mental status
- significant gastroparesis or gastric outlet obstruction or ileum
- known or suspected bowel obstruction or perforation
- pregnancy
- unable to give informed consent
